newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia hopes fire blight not virulent strain.
newsitem.headline: Australia hopes fire blight not virulent strain.

text.p: Australia said on Friday it hoped its first outbreak of the damaging fruit disease, fire blight, was of a non-virulent strain.
Primary Industries Minister John Anderson said tests were so far inconclusive but raised hopes the strain was not virulent.
"The tests ... continue to throw up different results from what might have been expected from the highly virulent strains of fire blight," Anderson told reporters.
The bacteria, a major apple and pear disease, was found for the first time recently on plants of the rose family in the botanical gardens at Adelaide and Melbourne.
Anderson reaffirmed the outbreak had no impact on Canberra's decision to reject apple imports from neighbouring New Zealand because of the possibility they could carry fire blight.
Investigations of allegations of possible sabotage by New Zealand were also continuing, he said.
"We will actively explore every possible pathway by which it came in," he said.
Fire blight is a disease that can devastate orchards, although the fruit is not affected.
